question_stem.en: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after an eye injury during a baseball game. He was batting for his high school team when the opposing pitcher made a wild throw and the baseball hit him in the right eye. The patient has since had diplopia that worsens when he looks up. On physical examination, he has mild periorbital ecchymosis, enophthalmos, and limited vertical movement of the right eye. Visual acuity and left eye examination are normal. CT scan of the face reveals an orbital floor fracture. {{exhibit_1}} Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
question_stem.zh: 一名16岁男孩因在棒球比赛中眼睛受伤被带到急诊科。他在高中队打棒球时，对方投手投出了一记坏球，棒球击中了他的右眼。此后，患者出现复视，向上看时复视加重。体格检查显示，他有轻度眶周瘀斑、眼球内陷以及右眼垂直运动受限。视力和左眼检查正常。面部CT扫描显示眶底骨折。{{exhibit_1}} 该患者最有可能出现以下哪种其他发现？

question.en: Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
question.zh: 该患者最有可能出现以下哪种其他发现？

D.en: Inability to puff out right cheek

E.en: Reduced sensation over right upper lip

summary.en:
This question tests the understanding of the anatomy of the orbit and the potential complications of an orbital floor fracture. Specifically, it assesses the knowledge of which cranial nerves and structures are at risk of injury with this type of fracture and the resulting clinical manifestations.

To solve this question, one must first identify the diagnosis of orbital floor fracture based on the clinical presentation and CT findings. Then, recall the anatomical structures located near the orbital floor, particularly the inferior rectus muscle and the infraorbital nerve. Finally, correlate potential nerve damage with the sensory distribution of the trigeminal nerve branches to determine the most likely additional finding.
summary.zh:
本题考察对眶部解剖结构的理解以及眶底骨折的潜在并发症。具体而言，它评估了对这种骨折可能导致哪些脑神经和结构受伤，以及由此产生的临床表现的知识。

要解决这个问题，首先必须根据临床表现和CT结果确定眶底骨折的诊断。然后，回忆位于眶底附近的解剖结构，特别是下直肌和眶下神经。最后，将潜在的神经损伤与三叉神经分支的感觉分布相关联，以确定最有可能的附加发现。

tags: Orbital floor fracture; Orbital trauma; Inferior rectus muscle entrapment; Diplopia; Infraorbital nerve; Trigeminal nerve (V2); Cranial nerves; Facial trauma; Ophthalmology; Emergency medicine
